Award.AwardTitle: What determines elevational distributions of Andean Birds? The relative importance of species interactions and physiology
Award.AbstractNarration:
Tropical mountain ranges have more bird species than any other region on earth. One reason for this high diversity is that bird communities change dramatically from the lowlands to the tops of mountains as species drop out and are replaced by others. The proposed research seeks to understand why so many species are restricted to just a portion of the elevation range available on the slopes of tropical mountains. The Manu Road in the Andes of southern Peru was chosen as the study site because it has the highest bird species diversity in the world (>1000 species). The researchers will first seek to determine the range of elevations that each species can potentially occupy based on their ability to tolerate different temperature ranges. Then, for species that do not occupy the entire range of conditions that they can tolerate physiologically, the researchers will study how interactions with other species, such as predators and competitors, may instead determine where species can live.

Tropical mountains have been targeted as the region where climate change will have the greatest impact on plants and animals with small ranges. More than a quarter of the world's endangered bird species are restricted to narrow elevation ranges on tropical mountains. Over the next century, many species of tropical mountains will have to move upslope as temperatures increase. Anything that prevents species from successfully moving to new environments upslope will greatly increase their risk of extinction. Currently, however, almost nothing is known about tolerances of any tropical species to changing temperatures. Species interactions are also likely to affect the extent to which species can move upslope in response to warming temperatures. This research will be the first to provide these data for many different species in a hyper-diverse region. The research team will also interact extensively with local communities, train many students from the US and from Peru, and generate resources such as photo-illustrated bird guides that can be used by the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tropical mountains contain some of the world's most diverse, but poorly understood wildlife communities. As climate change continues, these communities face especially severe challenges because most species that live in tropical mountains are restricted to just a small portion of the elevations potentially available to them. Our research was designed to determine if these species are limited to these small ranges because of physiological specialization to a narrow range of temperatures, or to some other factor such as their ability to withstand predators, the presence of other species that compete for the same resources, or because of their dependence on other species. The results of our study show that most Andean birds, the focus of our research, do have some adaptations for dealing with colder temperatures in the higher mountains. Most species, however, can tolerate a much wider range of temperatures than they currently experience and do not appear to be restricted to narrow elevation ranges by their intolerance of temperatures outside those that they normally experience.

Data from observations of more than 3000 nests, on the other hand, suggest that the kinds of predators that attack nests and overall losses of eggs and nestling to predators change greatly as one moves upslope from forests in the Amazonian lowlands to the cloud forests of higher elevations. In areas where losses to predators are very great, especially in the lowlands and foothills, species have adaptations that minimize the exposure of their eggs and nestlings to predators. These adaptations may be much more important than previously believed in restricting many species to narrow elevation ranges. At very high elevations, where temperatures are cold and losses to predators are moderately high year round, birds appear to adopt a very slow "pace of life" in which they put very little effort into breeding at any one time and live longer than their lowland counterparts.

Our study strongly suggests that understanding the consequences of global climate change will require more than just data on how temperature will change. We also need to understand how species interact with each other, their "pace of life,"  and how these interactions may be altered by changing climates. Our study further provided training and firsthand experience for a large number of field assistants (more than 90 from 12 diifferent countries) who worked on this project, many of whom are continuing to pursue education in ecological research. During the enormous amount of time assistants observed birds, they gathered valuable natural history data on many poorly known species: we described the first nests for more than 20 species during this study. Many of the assistants who worked with us are writing papers describing new nests and behaviors that they observed. We also worked extensively with local communities and with the general public to promote environmental awareness.
